[[File:190 LONDON Colet House.jpg|thumb|right|Colet House]] '''The Study Society''' is registered with the Charity Commission as Registered Charity Number 1155498.<ref name=charity>{{cite web|title=Charity Commission|url=http://www.charitycommission.gov.uk/find-charities/|publisher=The Charity Commission|accessdate=2 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=friendly>The Society was previously established according to the Friendly Societies Act, 1974, with the full name of ‘The Society for the Study of Normal Psychology’.</ref> Its stated objects are for the public benefit: # to advance the education of the public in religion, science, philosophy and the arts. # the promotion of moral and spiritual welfare.
It is based at Colet House, Barons Court, London.<ref>Colet House, 151 Talgarth Road, Barons Court, London W14 9DA, England</ref>
==History==
=== Introduction === The Society was registered in 1951 by Dr Francis C. Roles, four years after the death of his teacher, the Russian philosopher [[P. D. Ouspensky]], who had settled in England in 1921.<ref>{{cite book|last=Lachman|first=Gary|title=In Search of P. D. Ouspensky|year=2006|publisher=Quest Books|isbn=978-0-8356-0848-0|page=177}}</ref> The Society was set up to continue Ouspensky's work as a "School of the Fourth Way".<ref name="bridge14">{{cite journal|last = Eadie|first = Peter McGregor|journal = The Bridge|year = 2001|volume = 14|page = 27|publisher = The Study Society|title = The Odyssey of Francis C. Roles}}</ref><ref name=school>{{cite book|last=Ouspensky|first=P. D.|title=The Psychology of Man′s Possible Evolution|year=1974|publisher=Vintage Books|isbn=0-394-71943-3}} Originally published in 1940. Chapter: Lecture held Thursday, 23 September 1937</ref>
=== Fourth Way === The Fourth Way is a concept used by [[George Gurdjieff|G. I. Gurdjieff]] to describe an approach to self-development learned over years of travel in the East that combined what he saw as three established traditional "ways," or "schools" into a fourth way. These three ways were of the body, mind and emotions. According to his principles and instructions, Gurdjieff's method for awakening one's consciousness is different from that of the fakir, monk or yogi, so his discipline is also called the ‘[[Fourth Way]]’.<ref name=school /> His pupil [[P.D. Ouspensky]] from 1924 to 1947 made the term and its use central to his own teaching of Gurdjieff's ideas, and after Ouspensky's death, his students published a book titled ''The Fourth Way''<ref>{{cite book|last=Ouspensky|first=P. D.|title=The Fourth Way|date=1971|publisher=Vintage Books|isbn=0-394-71672-8}} Originally published in 1957.</ref> based on his lectures.
[[P. D. Ouspensky]] had developed his system of Self-discovery from the fundamental idea that ordinary human consciousness is incomplete and that it is possible for it to evolve further by personal effort and understanding.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ouspensky|first=P. D.|title=The Psychology of Man′s Possible Evolution|year=1974|publisher=Vintage Books|isbn=0-394-71943-3}} Originally published in 1940.</ref> Historically, this approach has generally been confined to closed orders, religious or otherwise and directed to the development of one particular human faculty: intellectual, emotional or physical.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ouspensky|first=P. D.|title=In Search of the Miraculous|year=1950|publisher=Routledge & Kegan Paul Ltd|isbn=0-7100-1910-6}} Chapter 15.</ref> Ouspensky promoted the practice of a ‘[[Fourth Way]]’, whereby ordinary people, remaining engaged in life, could work on all three aspects simultaneously. His teaching asserts the unity of the individual with the whole cosmos in both structure and potential.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ouspensky|first=P. D.|title=In Search of the Miraculous|year=1950|publisher=Routledge & Kegan Paul Ltd|isbn=0-7100-1910-6|pages=205–216}}</ref>
In Russia, Ouspensky had learned a system of knowledge and certain practical methods from [[George Gurdjieff|G. I. Gurdjieff]] and until his death in 1947<ref>{{cite book|last=Lachman|first=Gary|title=In Search of P. D. Ouspensky|year=2006|publisher=Quest Books|isbn=978-0-8356-0848-0|page=270}}</ref> Ouspensky devoted his life to further developing this system in the light of his own ideas. He established large groups of pupils in London and New York.<ref>{{cite book|last=Lachman|first=Gary|title=In Search of P. D. Ouspensky|year=2006|publisher=Quest Books|isbn=978-0-8356-0848-0|pages=178, 248}}</ref> Ouspensky’s London headquarters before and following World War II were at Colet House.<ref>{{cite book|last=Lachman|first=Gary|title=In Search of P.D. Ouspensky|year=2006|publisher=Quest Books|isbn=978-0-8356-0848-0|pages=230, 262}}</ref> This work led him to the conviction that the system was essentially incomplete; in particular it lacked a simple method to allow the ideas to develop naturally into behaviour and experience.<ref>{{cite book|title=Good Company II|year=2009|publisher=The Study Society|isbn=978-0-9547939-9-9|page=9}}Extract of audiences with Shantanand Saraswati.</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ouspensky Today: chronology 1941-1947|url=http://www.ouspenskytoday.org/wp/chronology/1941-1947-usa-england/|publisher=Ouspensky Today|accessdate=27 August 2016}}</ref>
=== ‘The Movements’ === The [[Gurdjieff movements|Movements]] were introduced into this country by Mme Ouspensky in the 1930s, when they were taught to [[P. D. Ouspensky|Ouspensky’s]] pupils at Lyne Place, Virginia Water and at Colet House.<ref>{{cite web|last=Howarth|first=Jessmin|title=Remember Inner Work|url=http://www.gurdjieff.org/howarth1.htm|publisher=Gurdjieff International Review Spring 2002}}</ref> The [[Gurdjieff movements|Movements]] were originally called Sacred Dances, Prayers and Exercises, and were known only in certain monasteries, temples, closed communities and esoteric orders scattered throughout the Middle East, the Hindu Kush and Tibet. During his travels in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, [[George Gurdjieff|G. I. Gurdjieff]] learned these sacred dances and their original music at their diverse sources and brought them together into a single repertoire which he then taught to his students in Europe.<ref>{{cite book|last=Howarth|first=Jessmin & Dushka|title=It’s Up To Ourselves|year=2009|publisher=Gurdjieff Heritage Society|isbn=978-0-9791926-0-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Mistlberger|first=P. T.|title=The Three Dangerous Magi|year=2010|publisher=O Books|isbn=978-1-84694-435-2|page=57}}</ref>
=== Meditation === Dr Roles continued with Ouspensky’s teaching for 13 years but in 1960, as a result of Ouspensky’s instruction to search for ‘the source of the system’, he came to meet [[Maharishi Mahesh Yogi]] in London. He recognised the method of mantra [[meditation]] that the Maharishi was disseminating as the simple method that Ouspensky had told him to find.<ref name=bridge14 /> The Study Society was instrumental in setting up the Maharishi’s seminal lecture to 5000 people at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in 1961<ref>{{cite book|last=Collin-Smith|first=Joyce|title=Call No Man Master|year=1988|publisher=Gateway Books|location=Bath, UK|isbn=0-946551-46-4|pages=142–144}}</ref><ref name=meditation>{{cite book|last=Mason|first=Paul|title=Maharishi Mahesh Yogi - The Biography of the Man who gave Transcendental Meditation to the World|year=1994|isbn=978-1-85230-571-0}} Chapter 5.</ref> which greatly raised his profile in Europe. Meditation was the inspiration of a group of Indian sages the most prominent of whom was Swami [[Brahmananda Saraswati]], Guru Deva.<ref>{{cite book|last=Roles|first=Francis|title=A Lasting Freedom|year=1972|publisher=The Society for the Study of Normal Psychology|page=8}}</ref> Nevertheless, it was not until Dr Roles was introduced to Swami Shantanand Saraswati, [[Shankaracharya]] of [[Jyotirmath]]—the head of the Advaita tradition in Northern India whose teaching of the non-dual philosophy of the Vedanta complemented and completed all he had learnt before—that he became convinced that his search was over.<ref name="Good Company II">{{cite book|title=Good Company II|year=2009|publisher=The Study Society|isbn=978-0-9547939-9-9|page=10}} Extract of audiences with Shantanand Saraswati.</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Good Company|year=1987|publisher=The Society for the Study of Normal Psychology|isbn=978-0-9561442-1-8|page=9}} Extract of audiences with Shantanand Saraswati.</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ouspensky Today: chronology 1960-1982|url=http://www.ouspenskytoday.org/wp/chronology/1960-1982-dr-f-c-roles-source-of-the-system/|publisher=Ouspensky Today|accessdate=27 August 2016}}</ref>
=== Mevlevi Turning of the Whirling Dervishes === In 1963 the Society formed a connection with Resuhi Baykara, a leader of the [[Rumi|Mevlevi]] Tradition in Istanbul who trained members of the Society in the discipline of [[Sufi whirling|Sufi Whirling Dance]].<ref>{{cite journal|last = Koren|first = Wilhelm|journal = The Bridge|year = 1997|volume = 12|page = 202|publisher = The Study Society|title = The Mevlevi}}</ref> This [[Sufism|Sufi]] discipline, originated by the 13th century mystic [[Rumi|Jalāl ad-Dīn Muhammad Rūmī]] is said to provide a means of acquiring inner stillness. The ceremony of the [[Sama (Sufism)|sema, or Mukabele]] takes place regularly at Colet House.<ref>{{cite web|title=Whirling Dervishes|url=http://www.studysociety.org/turning.html|publisher=The Study Society|accessdate=1 March 2012}}</ref>
=== Conclusion === Dr Francis C. Roles died in 1982<ref>{{cite journal|title=Obituary: Dr F.C. Roles|journal=British Medical Journal|date=July 1982|volume=285|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1499089/pdf/bmjcred00614-0067.pdf|page=67|pmc=1499089}}</ref> and Shantanand Saraswati in 1997.<ref>Obituary, The Hindhu Times, Sunday December 7, 1997</ref>
==Activities== The Study Society currently provides the following activities: * Study groups in which the teachings of [[P. D. Ouspensky]], Shantanand Saraswati and Dr F. C. Roles are discussed, as well as the philosophy of Non-Duality. * Teaching and practice of meditation. * Mevlevi Turning ([[Sufi whirling|Sufi Whirling Dance]]) and study of the poetry and music of the [[Rumi|Mevlevi]] tradition. * Public lectures.

Roles|title=Voyage of Discovery|publisher=The Society for the Study of Human Being|year=1992}} * {{cite book|last=Gerald de Symons Beckwith|title=Ouspensky’s Fourth Way: The story of the further development and completion of P D Ouspensky’s work by Dr Francis Roles.|publisher=Starnine Media & Publishing Ltd.|isbn=978-0-9931776-0-6|year=2015}}

[[Konrad Lorenz Institute for Evolution and Cognition Research]] |alma_mater = [[Ghent University]] |religion = |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |influences = |influenced = |known_for = [[Philosophy of Science]] |prizes = }} '''Werner Callebaut''' (October 7, 1952 – November 6, 2014) was a professor at the [[University of Hasselt]], scientific director of the [[Konrad Lorenz Institute for Evolution and Cognition Research]], editor and chief of ''[[Biological Theory (journal)|Biological Theory]]'', and president of The International Society for the History, Philosophy, and Social Studies of Biology. ==Biography== He attended high school at Koninklijk Atheneum [[Vilvoorde]], Belgium. During his undergraduate studies at the [[University of Ghent]], he was highly influenced by [[Leo Apostel]] and [[Etienne Vermeersch]]. In 1983, he received a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in philosophy from the University of Ghent with a dissertation entitled ''Contribution to a General Theory of Rationality on Evolutionary Foundations—With an Application to the Organization of Scientific Knowledge''. In 1995 he became a professor of philosophy at [[University of Hasselt]]. Between 1995 and 1999, he was a visiting fellow at Konrad Lorenz Institute for Evolution and Cognition Research (KLI) and, in 1999, he moved to Vienna, Austria to become scientific manager of KLI. In 2006, he became editor and chief of ''Biological Theory''. In 2013, he was elected president of The International Society for the History, Philosophy, and Social Studies of Biology (ISHPSSB). ==''Taking the Naturalistic Turn''== In his 1993 book ''Taking the naturalistic turn, or how real philosophy of science is done'',{{cite book|last1=Callebaut|first1=Werner|title=Taking the Naturalistic Turn, Or How Real Philosophy of Science Is Done|date=1993|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0226091877|pages=576|edition=1}} Callebaut interviewed a number of philosophers of on key topics in the philosophy of science. He then wove together the interviews into conversations on these key topics in the philosophy of science. ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{Cite news |last= Fuller |title= Taking the Naturalistic '''Wilfrid Augustine Hodges''', [[Fellow of the British Academy|FBA]] (born 27 May 1941) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[mathematician]], known for his work in [[model theory]].
==Life== Hodges was Professor of Mathematics at [[Queen Mary, University of London]] from 1987 to 2006, and is the author of books on [[logic]].
He attended [[New College, Oxford]] (1959–65), where he received degrees in both ''[[Literae Humaniores]]'' and (Christianic) [[Theology]]. In 1970 he was awarded a doctorate for a thesis in [[Logic]]. He lectured in both [[Philosophy]] and [[Mathematics]] at [[Bedford College (London)|Bedford College, University of London]]. He has held visiting appointments in the department of philosophy at the [[University of California]] and in the department of mathematics at [[University of Colorado at Boulder|University of Colorado]].
==Honors and awards== Hodges was President of the [[British Logic Colloquium]], of the European [[Association for Logic, Language and Information]] and of the [[Division of Logic, Methodology, and Philosophy of Science]].
In 2009 he was elected a Fellow of the [[British Academy]].
==Writing style== Wilfrid Hodges' books are written in an informal style. The "Notes on Notation" in his book "Model theory" end with the following characteristic sentence:
:'I' means I, 'we' means we.
When this 780-page book appeared in 1993, it became one of the standard textbooks on [[model theory]]. Due to its success an abbreviated version (but with a new chapter on [[stability theory (model theory)|stability theory]]) was published as a paperback.

Nguyễn Thị (mother) }} '''Đặng Thụy''' ({{lang-vi-hantu|鄧瑞}}, 1649–1735) was a [[Vietnam]]ese official of [[Revival Lê dynasty]].{{cite web|url=https://www.vanhoanghean.com.vn/chuyen-muc-goc-nhin-van-hoa/nhung-goc-nhin-van-hoa/dang-dinh-tuong-su-than-nha-tho|title=Đặng Đình Tướng - Sứ thần, nhà thơ|website=vanhoanghean.com.vn|accessdate=2017-09-06}} ==Biography== Đặng Thụy has a [[courtesy name]] '''Đình Tướng''' (廷相), [[pseudonym]] '''Trúc Trai Fairy Oldman''' (竹齋仙翁), [[nick name]] '''Fairy National Oldman''' (仙國老). He was born in 1649 at [[Lương Xá]] village, [[Chương Mỹ|Chương Đức]] district, [[Ứng Thiên]] prefect, [[Nam Thượng]] town. His father was Duke [[Đặng Tiến Thự|Trịnh Liễu]]Name ''Trịnh Liễu'' was presented by Trịnh lord. and his grandfather was general [[Đặng Thế Tài]], his forefather was Đặng Huấn who entered the restoration of the [[Revival Lê dynasty|Lê dynasty]].{{cite web|url=http://antgct.cand.com.vn/Nhan-vat/Co-duc-vuc-duoc-tuong-lai-314255/|title=Có đức, vực được tương lai | Báo Công an nhân dân điện tử|website=antgct.cand.com.vn|accessdate=2017-09-06}} [[Lương Xá]] village's Đặng clan has been fathered by general [[Đặng Dung]]. ==Works== {{div col}} * ''Trúc Ông phụng sứ tập'' (竹翁奉使集) * ''Linh Giang doanh vệ lục'' * ''Thuật cổ quy huấn lục'' * ''Dưỡng đức tính'' (養德性) * ''Thì triều thị'' * ''Thân chính nhân'' * ''Sùng chính học'' (崇政學) * ''Viễn nữ sắc'' (遠好色) * ''Trạch bộc ngự'' * ''Giới kiêu xa'' * ''Biện trung nịnh'' {{div col end}} ==See also== * [[Nguyễn Quý Đức]] ==References== {{reflist|4}} * [http://www.thivien.net/Đặng-Đình-Tướng/author-HGxbrX6twdxoQ9mhgJWL6A Đặng Thụy in ThiVien] * Phan Huy Chú (2008), ''[[Lịch triều hiến chương loại chí]], tập 1'', Nhà xuất bản Giáo dục * Viện Sử học (2007), ''Lịch sử Việt Nam, tập 3,'' Nhà xuất bản Giáo dục * [http://hodangmientrung.com/gia-pha/460.aspx Đặng Tộc Đại Tông Phả], Yến Quận công Đặng Tiến Thự viết năm 1683, Tiến sĩ Ứng Quận công Đặng Đình Tướng tục biên năm 1686, Thái Nhạc Quận công Đặng Sĩ Hàn tiếp tục tục biên năm 1745, Nguyễn Văn Thành giới thiệu, Nhà xuất bản Văn hóa Thông tin 2002 * [http://thantienvietnam.com/dao-quan/425-khoa-bang-trang-nguyen-viet-nam-18.html Khoa bảng trạng nguyên Việt Nam] * [http://archive.ihp.sinica.edu.tw/ttscgi/ttsquery?0:17461130:mctauac:TM%3D%BEH%A7%CA%AC%DB (清)鄧廷相] {{DEFAULTSORT:Thụy, Đặng}} [[Category:1649 births]] [[Category:1735 deaths]] [[Category:People from Hanoi]] [[Category:Vietnamese Confucianists]] [[Category:Vietnamese male poets]] [[Category:Lê dynasty officials]]
